Is the `--make-remote` flag removed in recent versions? I cannot find it in the recent versions, and I could not find anything in the [changelog](https://rclone.org/changelog/) either about this.

If yes, then what is the way of creating a remote with command-line parameters. I had this working with previous versions via the `--make-remote` flag, but after upgrading (to `v1.51.0`) it stopped working.

Thanks for replying! The `:backend:` will do the job for me. 

A minor concern, I have a script which uses rclone and recently it stopped working. And hence the comment above. Strange that you mention `--make-remote` never got merged, because my script uses `--make-remote` (and now it fails with no such flag error). FWIW, the script is 1-1.5 years old and used to work fine and used rclone from Arch Linux package repo. I don't run this script regularly, and probably that's why I recently found out about the error, when I tried to run it after a few months. Anyway, this is just a side note, and shouldn't concern you much.

> Strange that you mention `--make-remote` never got merged, because my script uses `--make-remote` (and now it fails with no such flag error).

I grepped the git log and the changelog - I don't think I ever merged or even implemented that flag which is odd! The commits attached to this issue all talk about the `:backend:` syntax which is a much better idea IMHO.
How do you use this feature between two different s3 backends ?

> How do you use this feature between two different s3 backends ?

You have to make remotes - the on the fly syntax isn't powerful enough to deal with two backends of the same type. I had an idea to fix this with putting the config in the on the fly syntax so :s3,endpoint=blah,region=blah: but I haven't done that yet!

> @ecthiender checkout https://rclone.org/commands/rclone_config_create/ for creating backends programatically or use the `:backend:` syntax as described here: https://rclone.org/docs/#syntax-of-remote-paths
>

This is awesome! Exactly what I was looking for. Thanks, @ncw! I couldn't find this from https://forum.rclone.org/t/can-rclone-be-run-solely-with-command-line-options-no-config-no-env-vars/6314/5 and the topic is closed. Maybe you could save some people time by pointing to this issue from there?

https://forum.rclone.org/t/can-rclone-be-run-solely-with-command-line-options-no-config-no-env-vars/6314/5 is closed, so Ive put this here. Documentation on this was a real struggle for me. In the hopes this helps others, heres an inline command to backup a DigitalOcean Spaces bucket locally to `./bucket`:

```sh
rclone sync \
    --s3-provider="DigitalOcean" \
    --s3-env-auth="false" \
    --s3-access-key-id=$STORAGE_ACCESS_KEY_ID \
    --s3-secret-access-key=$STORAGE_ACCESS_SECRET \
    --s3-endpoint=$STORAGE_ENDPOINT \
    --s3-acl=private \
    :s3:$STORAGE_BUCKET \
    ./bucket"
```

Replace the `$VARS` where appropriate. Im not a fan of side-effect powdered code where it can be helped (i.e. `rclone.conf`), so making this more functional was a deal breaker. Its similar to having a`./rclone.conf` file like this:

```txt
[spaces]
type=s3
provider=DigitalOcean
env_auth=false
access_key_id=$STORAGE_ACCESS_KEY_ID
secret_access_key=$STORAGE_ACCESS_SECRET
endpoint=$STORAGE_ENDPOINT
acl=private
```

And then running a command like this:

```
rclone sync --config=./rclone.conf spaces:$STORAGE_BUCKET ./bucket"
```

I also dont like credentials stored in multiple locations on the system, so taking values from my existing `.env` file and pushing them in via flags was the only way. Dont keep these env vars set in the systems shell unless its in something like Docker.

```shell
rclone sync \
    --s3-provider="DigitalOcean" \
    --s3-env-auth="false" \
    --s3-access-key-id=$STORAGE_ACCESS_KEY_ID \
    --s3-secret-access-key=$STORAGE_ACCESS_SECRET \
    --s3-endpoint=$STORAGE_ENDPOINT \
    --s3-acl=private \
    :s3:$STORAGE_BUCKET \
    ./bucket"
```
